did.head: Collection Summary
did.abstract: John J. Wingar, 1833-1907, was a Methodist clergyman and Arizona pioneer. This collection includes reminisces, treatises, and petitions relating to early Arizona topics.

repository.label: Repository:
repository.corpname: University of Arizona Libraries, Special Collections

accessrestrict.head: Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: There are no restrictions on this collection.

prefercite.head: Credit Line
prefercite.p: Papers of John J. Wingar (AZ 089). Special Collections, University of Arizona Libraries.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Methodist clergyman and Arizona pioneer. Wingar moved to Prescott in 1877, and later lived in Florence, Pinal, Globe, and Tempe. He was active in establishing a school at the San Carlos Apache Indian Reservation.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection is organized by type of material.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Remininscences, treatise, and petition relating to early Arizona topics. Includes 24-page typescript of Wingar's reminiscences, and his daughter, Alice B. Gregg's account of an encounter with Apaches. Also includes a treatise entitled "Abolition of the Indian Factory System", author unknown, and a petition to the Secretary of the Interior regarding construction of the Arizona canal on the Salt River, author unknown.
